title: Coding Provenance Workshop. First Edition
text:
From 18 to 21 December 2025 — Leuphana University
Room C.40.606, Seminarraum, Main Building at Leuphana University

This workshop explores the emerging field of computational provenance research, bringing together scholars, curators, and data scientists to discuss digital approaches to provenance, data modeling, and computational analysis.

What You Need

You need to bring your own laptop
A Google account, as we’ll be using Google Colab for hands-on sessions.

If you prefer, you may use your own local environment (e.g., Visual Studio Code or Jupyter Notebooks).

We will be coding in Python throughout the workshop.



Modules

OCR

Data Models
Python Language

From Text to Data
Data Analysis

Data Visualization

Resources



December Schedule




Day 1 – Thursday, December 18



15:30 – Participant registration and reception


16:00 – Informal panel (Sandra, Lynn, Giulia, Bárbara)


17:00 – Food cocktail (ends by 18:00 sharp)


18:30 – Museum & drinks





Day 2 – Friday, December 19



09:00 – From Text to Data (OCR)


10:30 – Coffee Break


11:00 – From Data to Structured Data (Text processing in NLP, Standard Formats, LOD)


13:00 – Lunch Break


14:15 – Data Analysis: quantitative & computational techniques (NLP for text analysis)


15:30 – Coffee Break


16:00 – Data Analysis (continued)


17:30 – Salt Museum





Day 3 – Saturday, December 20



09:30 – Knowledge Design


13:00 – Lunch Break


14:00 – Information Visualisation Session


16:00 – Information Visualisation (continued)


17:30 – Work in groups





Day 4 – Sunday, December 21



10:00 – Participants’ presentations


13:00 – Wrap-up & goodbye

title: Our Mission and Vision & Organizers
text:
The workshop
This workshop is a collaboration between the Provenance Lab and the Getty Provenance Index.
After decades working as provenance and art history researchers, we have witnessed the field changing and evolving in many different ways. We believe that the intersection between computational techniques and a more data-driven approach can not only reveal patterns, structures, and dynamics that were hard to uncover through close reading, but also lead us to new research questions that were previously impossible to answer or to know. We call it computational provenance, which is provenance research using statistics, network analysis, optical character recognition, large language models, and natural language processing for research purposes.
Our goal with this workshop is to provide tools to researchers and practitioners and to introduce them to methodologies that can inspire them to create new policies and to use different methods or techniques within their institutions or in their personal research. We believe that to continue working toward computational provenance we all need to understand all the possibilites and how the field can change. We believe that interdisciplinary work with computer scientists or digital humanities specialists is extremely valuable, but for fair and equal collaboration we need a good understanding of what can be done and how. That is why our workshop aims to give participants a first encounter with theories, methods, and tools, to empower them.



Organizers and Instructors




Bárbara Romero Ferrón


Provenance Lab, Leuphana University of Lüneburg

Other Instructors & Organizers

Fabio Mariani

Affiliation: University of Augsburg
Fabio is a Research Associate at the University of Augsburg and a PhD candidate at Leuphana University Lüneburg on “Vague, Incomplete, Subjective, and Uncertain Information in Digital History.” He is also an affiliated researcher at the Provenance Lab. From 2020 to 2024, he was a Research Associate at Leuphana University Lüneburg . He holds a Master’s degree in Digital Humanities from the University of Bologna (2020) and a Bachelor’s degree in History. During his studies, he participated in several research projects involving Semantic Web technologies at the Digital Humanities Advanced Research Centre (DH.arc) and OpenCitations.



Max Koss

Affiliation: Provenance Lab, Leuphana University of Lüneburg
